hub.title: Retiring to Williamson County, TX
hub.subtitle: Your Complete Relocation Guide
hub.heroHeadline: Thinking About Retiring to Williamson County?
hub.heroSubtext: Everything you need to know about relocating to one of Texas's fastest-growing and most livable counties.
hub.seoTitle: Retiring to Williamson County, TX | Your Complete Relocation Guide
hub.metaDescription: Comprehensive guide to retiring in Williamson County, TX. Explore cost of living, healthcare, 55+ communities, tax benefits, and city-by-city comparisons for Round Rock, Georgetown, Cedar Park, and more.

sections.title: Cost of Living
sections.content:
Williamson County offers a cost of living that is highly competitive compared to the major metros many retirees are leaving behind. Median home prices range significantly by city, from around $270K in Florence and $280K in Taylor to $420K in Cedar Park, giving retirees real options depending on budget and lifestyle preferences. Georgetown, home to the massive Sun City community, sits around $400K median, while Round Rock comes in at $380K. If you are relocating from California, the Pacific Northwest, or the Chicago area, you will likely find that your housing dollar stretches considerably further here.

Property tax rates across the county generally fall between 2.0% and 2.3%, which is on par with other Central Texas counties. However, Texas offers a generous homestead exemption for homeowners 65 and older, including a school district tax freeze, which can significantly reduce your annual tax burden. There is no state income tax in Texas, which is a major draw for retirees living on fixed incomes, pensions, or retirement account withdrawals.

Grocery costs in Williamson County are roughly comparable to the national average. H-E-B, the beloved Texas grocery chain, has multiple locations throughout the county and is known for competitive pricing and high-quality store brands. Utilities tend to run slightly higher in summer due to air conditioning, but overall day-to-day expenses are manageable. For retirees comparing Williamson County to places like Austin proper, you will generally find lower property taxes, more affordable housing, and a quieter pace of life without sacrificing access to big-city amenities.

sections.title: Healthcare Access
sections.content:
Access to quality healthcare is one of the most important factors for anyone considering retirement in a new area, and Williamson County delivers strong options. The county is anchored by three major hospital systems. St. David's Georgetown Hospital serves the northern part of the county and is the closest full-service hospital to Sun City Texas. Baylor Scott & White Medical Center in Round Rock is a large, comprehensive facility with a wide range of specialties including cardiology, orthopedics, and oncology. Ascension Seton Williamson in Round Rock provides additional hospital capacity and emergency services.

Cedar Park Regional Medical Center serves the western corridor, covering Cedar Park and Leander residents. Taylor Regional Hospital, while smaller, provides essential services and emergency care for those in the eastern part of the county. For specialized care, the entire Dell Medical School and Seton network in Austin is within a 30- to 45-minute drive from most Williamson County cities.

Medicare acceptance is broadly strong across the county. Most primary care physicians, specialists, and urgent care clinics accept Medicare, though it is always wise to verify with individual providers before scheduling. The county has seen significant growth in medical offices, urgent care facilities, and outpatient clinics in recent years, particularly along the I-35 corridor in Round Rock and Georgetown. Home health agencies, physical therapy practices, and senior-focused clinics are also well represented throughout the area, making it straightforward to build a reliable healthcare team close to home.

sections.title: Climate & Weather
sections.content:
Williamson County enjoys a subtropical climate with mild winters, long warm seasons, and over 230 sunny days per year. For retirees relocating from the Midwest, Northeast, or Pacific Northwest, the biggest adjustment is typically the summer heat. June through September regularly brings temperatures above 95 degrees, and triple-digit days are common in July and August. However, the trade-off is that winters are remarkably mild. Daytime highs from December through February generally sit in the mid-50s to low 60s, with overnight lows rarely dipping below freezing for more than a few nights each winter. Significant snowfall is extremely rare.

Spring and fall are the standout seasons in Central Texas. March through May and October through November offer comfortable temperatures in the 70s and 80s, making them ideal for outdoor activities, gardening, and exploring the area's parks and trails. Rainfall averages around 34 inches per year, with the wettest months typically being May and October. Severe weather, including thunderstorms and occasional hail, is possible during spring, but the area is not in the most active tornado zone.

For retirees coming from colder climates, the adjustment to summer heat is real but manageable. Most homes and businesses are well air-conditioned, and many outdoor activities can be shifted to mornings or evenings. The mild winters mean far less time shoveling snow, dealing with ice, and bundling up, which is a significant quality-of-life improvement for many older adults with joint or mobility concerns.

sections.title: 55+ Communities
sections.content:
Williamson County is home to Sun City Texas in Georgetown, the largest active adult community in the state and one of the largest in the entire country. Developed by Del Webb, Sun City encompasses over 9,000 homes spread across 5,300 acres. It is a gated, age-restricted community (55+) with an extraordinary range of amenities: three golf courses, multiple pools, tennis and pickleball courts, a fitness center, woodworking and ceramics studios, and over 50 chartered clubs and interest groups. The community has its own on-site amenity centers, restaurants, and a full calendar of social events. Sun City is a self-contained world for active retirees who want built-in community, activities, and neighbors in a similar life stage.

Beyond Sun City, The Delaney at Georgetown Village is a newer option offering independent living, assisted living, and memory care in a resort-style setting. It provides a continuum of care that appeals to retirees who want flexibility as their needs change over time.

While Georgetown dominates the 55+ landscape, many retirees in Williamson County choose age-friendly neighborhoods in other cities that are not age-restricted but still offer a comfortable, low-maintenance lifestyle. Single-story homes in master-planned communities throughout Round Rock, Cedar Park, and Leander are popular choices. Neighborhoods like Brushy Creek and Forest Creek in Round Rock, and Crystal Falls in Leander, attract retirees who prefer mixed-age settings while still enjoying well-maintained common areas, trails, and community pools. The key is finding the right balance between dedicated senior amenities and proximity to family, healthcare, and daily conveniences.

sections.title: Things to Do
sections.content:
Retirees in Williamson County enjoy an impressive range of recreational and cultural activities. Outdoor enthusiasts will find well-maintained parks and trails throughout the area. Garey Park in Georgetown is a 525-acre gem with hiking and biking trails, fishing ponds, an equestrian area, and a dog park. Lake Georgetown offers boating, fishing, and lakeside camping. Blue Hole Park, also in Georgetown, features a natural swimming area along the South San Gabriel River. The Brushy Creek Trail system in Round Rock and Cedar Park provides miles of paved paths ideal for walking and cycling.

Pickleball has exploded in popularity across the county, with dedicated courts at Sun City, Clay Madsen Recreation Center in Round Rock, and several municipal parks. Golf options are plentiful, including Sun City's three courses, Cimarron Hills in Georgetown, Avery Ranch Golf Club in Austin (minutes from Cedar Park), and the Crystal Falls Golf Club in Leander.

Georgetown's historic downtown square is a beloved destination for dining, shopping, antique browsing, and attending community events. The Round Rock Express minor league baseball team plays at Dell Diamond, drawing fans from across the county for affordable family entertainment. The Williamson Museum in Georgetown and the Round Rock Public Library's active programming offer cultural enrichment.

For those who enjoy day trips, Austin's live music scene, museums, and restaurants are 20 to 45 minutes away. The Texas Hill Country wine trail is an easy weekend outing. Community centers throughout the county host fitness classes, art workshops, card groups, and social events specifically designed for older adults.

sections.title: Tax Benefits
sections.content:
Texas is one of only nine states with no state income tax, and this is a significant financial advantage for retirees. Pension income, Social Security benefits, IRA and 401(k) withdrawals, and investment income are all free from state income tax. For retirees relocating from states like California, Illinois, New York, or Minnesota, the tax savings can be substantial, often amounting to thousands of dollars per year depending on income level.

While Texas does rely more heavily on property taxes to fund local services, Williamson County offers important relief for seniors. Texas law provides a mandatory homestead exemption for homeowners aged 65 and older, which includes an additional $10,000 exemption from school district taxes on top of the standard homestead exemption. Even more valuable is the school district tax ceiling, which freezes your school property tax amount at the level it was in the year you turned 65 or the year you acquired the property, whichever is later. This means that as property values rise, your school tax portion does not increase.

Many local taxing entities in Williamson County, including the county itself and several cities, also offer optional homestead exemptions for seniors. The details vary by jurisdiction, so it is worth checking with the Williamson County Tax Assessor's office or your city's tax office to understand the full picture. Additionally, Texas has no estate tax and no inheritance tax, which simplifies financial and estate planning for retirees. Overall, Texas's tax structure is designed in a way that meaningfully benefits retirees, particularly those on fixed incomes who can take advantage of the property tax protections available to older homeowners.

sections.title: Safety & Crime
sections.content:
Williamson County consistently ranks as one of the safest large counties in Texas. Compared to neighboring Travis County (Austin), Williamson County has noticeably lower violent crime and property crime rates. Cities like Georgetown, Cedar Park, and Round Rock regularly appear on statewide and national lists of safe cities. This is a meaningful consideration for retirees who prioritize personal safety and a secure living environment.

The county benefits from well-funded law enforcement agencies, including the Williamson County Sheriff's Office and municipal police departments in each city. Community policing initiatives are common, with many neighborhoods participating in programs like National Night Out and neighborhood watch groups. Georgetown, in particular, maintains a strong community policing presence that residents frequently praise.

Sun City Texas has its own gated entry with staffed access points, adding an extra layer of security for residents. Many of the master-planned communities throughout the county also feature controlled access, well-lit streets, and security patrols.

That said, no area is completely free from crime, and it is always wise to take standard precautions. Package theft and vehicle break-ins do occur, particularly in higher-traffic areas along the I-35 corridor. However, the overall sense of safety throughout Williamson County is one of the most commonly cited reasons retirees choose to relocate here. The small-town atmosphere, even in the larger cities like Round Rock and Cedar Park, contributes to a feeling of community where neighbors know each other and look out for one another.

sections.title: Transportation
sections.content:
Williamson County is primarily car-dependent, which is typical of Central Texas and most of the Sun Belt. The major highways provide straightforward access across the region: I-35 runs north-south through the heart of the county connecting Georgetown, Round Rock, and Pflugerville to Austin. Highway 183 provides an alternative north-south route, while the 45 Toll Road and 130 Toll Road offer faster east-west and bypass options. Most daily errands, medical appointments, and social activities require a car.

For retirees who rely on or prefer public transit, options are limited but improving. Capital Metro, Austin's transit authority, extends bus service into portions of Leander and some parts of the county. The MetroRail Red Line runs from downtown Austin to Leander, with stops in several communities along the way. This can be useful for day trips into Austin without needing to drive or park. However, Capital Metro service does not cover Georgetown, Hutto, Taylor, or the more rural parts of the county.

Ride-sharing services like Uber and Lyft are available throughout the county, with the most reliable coverage in Round Rock, Cedar Park, and Georgetown. Several local organizations and senior service agencies provide medical transport and ride assistance for older adults who no longer drive. The Williamson County chapter of the American Red Cross and various nonprofit organizations offer volunteer driver programs.

The Austin-Bergstrom International Airport is approximately 30 to 50 minutes from most Williamson County cities, depending on traffic and location, making air travel for visiting family or taking trips reasonably convenient.

sections.title: City-by-City Overview
sections.content:
Georgetown is the county seat and the clear leader for dedicated senior living, thanks to Sun City Texas, its charming historic downtown square, and St. David's Georgetown Hospital. Round Rock is the largest city in the county and offers the most urban conveniences, including major hospitals, extensive shopping and dining, and proximity to Austin. Cedar Park is a growing city on the western edge of the county with Hill Country access, strong medical facilities, and excellent trail systems.

Leander is one of the fastest-growing cities in Texas, offering more affordable housing than Cedar Park with growing amenities and a MetroRail connection to Austin. Pflugerville provides suburban value with a diverse, welcoming community, a popular lake, and easy access to both Round Rock and Austin. Hutto maintains a genuine small-town feel with very affordable housing, rapid growth, and a strong community spirit centered around its distinctive hippo mascot.

Taylor is the most affordable city in the county, with a historic downtown square, deep agricultural roots, and newfound energy from the nearby Samsung semiconductor campus. Liberty Hill offers scenic Hill Country living with a more rural, spacious atmosphere and a rapidly growing community. Jarrell is a small but quickly developing town at the northern edge of the county, appealing to retirees seeking affordable homes and a tight-knit community. Florence is the most rural option, offering the lowest home prices, peaceful countryside living, and proximity to Hill Country lakes and outdoor recreation.

faqs.question: Is Williamson County a good place to retire?
faqs.answer: Williamson County is widely considered one of the best places to retire in Texas. The county offers a compelling combination of affordable housing, excellent healthcare through hospitals like St. David's Georgetown and Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock, and no state income tax. Sun City Texas in Georgetown is the largest active adult community in the state, providing a built-in social network for thousands of retirees. The area features low crime rates, over 230 sunny days per year, and a wide range of outdoor and cultural activities. With ten distinct cities to choose from, retirees can find the right fit whether they prefer a small-town atmosphere, suburban convenience, or Hill Country scenery.

faqs.question: What is the cost of living in Georgetown TX?
faqs.answer: Georgetown's cost of living is moderate by Central Texas standards. The median home price is approximately $400K, though options range widely depending on the neighborhood and whether you are looking inside Sun City or elsewhere. Property tax rates are around 2.1%, but seniors 65 and older benefit from a homestead exemption and a school tax freeze that limits future increases. Groceries, dining, and everyday expenses are in line with national averages. Compared to Austin, Georgetown generally offers lower housing costs and property taxes with a quieter, more relaxed lifestyle. Retirees relocating from higher-cost states like California or Illinois will find their money goes significantly further.

faqs.question: What 55+ communities are in Williamson County?
faqs.answer: The largest and most well-known 55+ community in Williamson County is Sun City Texas in Georgetown. Developed by Del Webb, Sun City has over 9,000 homes and is the biggest active adult community in the state. It offers three golf courses, multiple pools, fitness facilities, over 50 clubs, and a packed social calendar. The Delaney at Georgetown Village is another option, offering independent living, assisted living, and memory care in a single campus. Beyond these dedicated communities, many retirees choose single-story homes in master-planned neighborhoods throughout Round Rock, Cedar Park, and Leander that are not age-restricted but offer a comfortable, low-maintenance lifestyle.

faqs.question: Does Texas have state income tax?
faqs.answer: No, Texas does not have a state income tax. This applies to all types of income, including pensions, Social Security benefits, IRA and 401(k) withdrawals, and investment income. For retirees, this can mean significant annual savings compared to states that tax retirement income. Texas funds its government primarily through sales tax and property taxes. While property tax rates in Williamson County range from 2.0% to 2.3%, seniors aged 65 and older receive additional homestead exemptions and a school district tax freeze that helps offset these costs. There is also no state estate tax or inheritance tax in Texas.

faqs.question: What hospitals are near Sun City Texas?
faqs.answer: Sun City Texas in Georgetown is served primarily by St. David's Georgetown Hospital, which is located just a few minutes from the community. St. David's Georgetown offers emergency services, surgical care, imaging, and a range of outpatient specialties. For more specialized care, Baylor Scott & White Medical Center in Round Rock is approximately 20 minutes south and provides comprehensive services including cardiology, oncology, and orthopedics. Ascension Seton Williamson, also in Round Rock, adds another full-service hospital option. Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is about 25 minutes west. For highly specialized procedures, the Dell Medical School and Seton network in Austin is within a 40-minute drive.

faqs.question: Is Round Rock safe for seniors?
faqs.answer: Round Rock is considered a safe city and regularly appears on lists of the safest cities in Texas. The city's crime rates, both violent and property crime, are well below the national average and significantly lower than neighboring Austin. The Round Rock Police Department is active in community policing and neighborhood engagement programs. Many of the city's master-planned neighborhoods feature well-lit streets, maintained common areas, and an engaged residential community. While no city is entirely free of crime, seniors in Round Rock generally report feeling safe in their neighborhoods, at parks, and when going about daily activities.

faqs.question: What is there to do for retirees in Cedar Park?
faqs.answer: Cedar Park offers a growing selection of activities for retirees. The Brushy Creek Trail system provides miles of paved paths for walking and cycling through scenic green space. The Cedar Park Recreation Center hosts fitness classes, social programs, and community events. Shopping and dining options are plentiful at 1890 Ranch and along the US-183 corridor. The H-E-B Center at Cedar Park hosts concerts, minor league hockey and basketball games, and community events throughout the year. Cedar Park's western location provides easy access to the Hill Country, Lake Travis, and the Texas wine country. Austin's cultural attractions are just 20 to 30 minutes to the south.

georgetown.name: Georgetown
georgetown.seoTitle: Retiring to Georgetown, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
georgetown.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Georgetown, TX. Home to Sun City Texas, the largest 55+ community in the state. Explore healthcare, housing, cost of living, and things to do for retirees.
georgetown.heroSubtext: Home to Sun City Texas and a historic downtown square that makes Georgetown the top retirement destination in the county.
georgetown.content:
Georgetown is the undisputed center of retirement living in Williamson County, and for good reason. As the county seat and home to Sun City Texas, Georgetown has built a reputation as one of the best places to retire in all of Texas. The city blends small-town Texas charm with the amenities and healthcare access that retirees need.

Sun City Texas is the headline attraction. Developed by Del Webb, this massive active adult community spans over 5,300 acres and includes more than 9,000 homes, making it the largest 55+ community in the state. Sun City is a gated, age-restricted community with an astonishing range of amenities: three 18-hole golf courses, indoor and outdoor pools, a fitness center, tennis and pickleball courts, woodworking and ceramics studios, a ballroom, a dog park, and multiple dining options. With over 50 chartered clubs covering everything from photography to line dancing to veterans' groups, the social life inside Sun City is rich and varied. Many residents describe the community as having a small-town feel within itself, where neighbors become close friends and there is always something to do.

Beyond Sun City, Georgetown's historic downtown square is one of the most charming in Texas. The square features locally owned restaurants, antique shops, boutiques, art galleries, and regular community events including Market Days, a summer concert series, and the famous Red Poppy Festival each April. The Williamson Museum on the square provides local history and rotating exhibits.

Healthcare in Georgetown is anchored by St. David's Georgetown Hospital, which provides emergency services, surgical care, imaging, and outpatient specialties. The hospital is conveniently located just minutes from Sun City, and multiple medical office complexes nearby house primary care physicians, cardiologists, orthopedic specialists, and other providers who accept Medicare.

Outdoor recreation is a major draw. Garey Park is a 525-acre city park with miles of hiking and biking trails, fishing ponds, a playground, an equestrian area, and a dog park. Lake Georgetown, managed by the Army Corps of Engineers, offers boating, fishing, swimming, and camping along the San Gabriel River. Blue Hole Park features a natural spring-fed swimming area in the heart of the city. The San Gabriel Trail system connects parks and green spaces throughout Georgetown, providing paved paths for walking and cycling.

Georgetown's cost of living is moderate for Central Texas. The median home price is approximately $400K, with a wide range available from smaller homes in older neighborhoods to custom builds in newer developments. Property tax rates are around 2.1%, and seniors 65 and older benefit from homestead exemptions and a school district tax freeze. The city has a strong sense of community, active volunteer organizations, and a welcoming atmosphere that consistently draws retirees from across the country.
highlights: Sun City Texas - largest 55+ community in the state with 9,000+ homes
St. David's Georgetown Hospital
Historic downtown square with shops and restaurants
Garey Park - 525-acre park with trails, fishing, and equestrian area
Blue Hole Park natural swimming area
Lake Georgetown boating and fishing
Inner Space Cavern
Red Poppy Festival and community events
georgetown.healthcare: St. David's Georgetown Hospital is the primary hospital serving the city, offering emergency services, surgical care, and outpatient specialties. Multiple medical office complexes near the hospital house primary care physicians and specialists. For advanced specialty care, Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock and the Seton network in Austin are within a 25- to 40-minute drive.
georgetown.thingsToDo: Georgetown offers outstanding outdoor recreation including Garey Park (525 acres), Lake Georgetown, Blue Hole Park, and the San Gabriel Trail system. The historic downtown square is home to restaurants, antique shops, and regular community events. Sun City's extensive amenities, including golf, pickleball, pools, and 50+ clubs, provide a self-contained social life for its residents.
georgetown.safety: Georgetown is consistently rated as one of the safest cities in Texas, with low crime rates and an active community policing program that residents value.

faqs.question: What is Sun City Texas in Georgetown?
faqs.answer: Sun City Texas is the largest active adult (55+) community in the state of Texas, located in Georgetown. Developed by Del Webb, it features over 9,000 homes, three golf courses, multiple pools, fitness facilities, over 50 chartered clubs, and a full calendar of social events. It is a gated, age-restricted community with its own amenity centers and dining options.

faqs.question: What hospitals are in Georgetown TX?
faqs.answer: Georgetown is served by St. David's Georgetown Hospital, which provides emergency services, surgery, imaging, and outpatient care. The hospital is located near Sun City and is easily accessible from most parts of the city. For more specialized care, Baylor Scott & White Medical Center in Round Rock is about 20 minutes south, and the Dell Medical School network in Austin is within 40 minutes.

faqs.question: Is Georgetown TX a good place to retire?
faqs.answer: Georgetown is widely regarded as one of the best retirement destinations in Texas. It is home to Sun City Texas, the state's largest 55+ community, and offers a charming historic downtown, excellent healthcare at St. David's Georgetown Hospital, low crime rates, and abundant outdoor recreation. The cost of living is moderate, and the strong sense of community makes it particularly welcoming for retirees.

round-rock.name: Round Rock
round-rock.seoTitle: Retiring to Round Rock, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
round-rock.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Round Rock, TX. Explore hospitals, housing, recreation, and why Round Rock's proximity to Austin makes it ideal for active retirees.
round-rock.heroSubtext: Urban convenience and top-tier healthcare just 20 minutes from Austin, with a welcoming community feel.
round-rock.content:
Round Rock is the largest city in Williamson County and offers retirees the most comprehensive urban amenities in the area. With a population of approximately 135,000, Round Rock provides the convenience of a mid-sized city while maintaining a friendly, community-oriented atmosphere. Its location along I-35, roughly 20 minutes north of downtown Austin, gives residents easy access to the state capital's cultural attractions, dining, and entertainment without the higher costs and congestion of living in Austin itself.

Healthcare is one of Round Rock's strongest assets for retirees. The city is home to two major hospitals: Baylor Scott & White Medical Center - Round Rock, a comprehensive facility with specialties including cardiology, oncology, orthopedics, neurology, and a robust emergency department, and Ascension Seton Williamson, which provides additional hospital services and emergency care. The concentration of medical facilities along the I-35 and University Boulevard corridors means that specialists, urgent care clinics, imaging centers, and outpatient surgery centers are all within easy reach. Medicare acceptance is strong across most providers in the area.

Round Rock's recreational options are excellent. Old Settlers Park is a 645-acre park featuring sports fields, a lake, walking trails, a memorial, and community event space. Dell Diamond is home to the Round Rock Express, a minor league baseball affiliate, offering affordable entertainment throughout the season. Clay Madsen Recreation Center provides indoor and outdoor swimming pools, a fitness center, gymnasium, walking track, and regular programming including fitness classes and social events for older adults. The Brushy Creek Trail system, shared with Cedar Park, offers miles of paved paths for walking and cycling.

Shopping and dining in Round Rock are notably strong. The La Frontera shopping district and Round Rock Premium Outlets provide major retail options. IKEA, Bass Pro Shops, and a wide variety of restaurants line the I-35 corridor. The downtown area along Main Street has been revitalized in recent years with local restaurants, shops, and a growing arts scene.

Housing in Round Rock spans a wide range. The median home price is approximately $380K, with options from townhomes and condos starting in the low $200Ks to custom homes in established neighborhoods pushing above $500K. While there are no age-restricted 55+ communities in Round Rock, several neighborhoods are particularly popular with retirees due to their single-story homes, well-maintained common areas, and convenient locations. Brushy Creek, Behrens Ranch, and Forest Creek are frequently cited as top choices for older adults.

Round Rock's location and infrastructure make it a practical choice for retirees who want easy access to healthcare, shopping, dining, and Austin while living in a safer, more affordable, and more manageable community.
highlights: Proximity to Austin (20 minutes)
Baylor Scott & White Medical Center
Ascension Seton Williamson Hospital
Clay Madsen Recreation Center
Old Settlers Park (645 acres)
Dell Diamond - Round Rock Express baseball
La Frontera and Premium Outlets shopping
Brushy Creek Trail system
round-rock.healthcare: Round Rock has the strongest healthcare infrastructure in Williamson County, with two major hospitals: Baylor Scott & White Medical Center and Ascension Seton Williamson. Both offer comprehensive services including emergency, surgical, and specialty care. Numerous specialist offices, urgent care clinics, and outpatient centers line the I-35 and University Boulevard corridors.
round-rock.thingsToDo: Round Rock offers Dell Diamond baseball, Old Settlers Park (645 acres), Clay Madsen Recreation Center with pools and fitness classes, the Brushy Creek Trail system, and extensive shopping and dining along La Frontera and I-35. Downtown Round Rock on Main Street features local restaurants and a growing arts scene. Austin's attractions are just 20 minutes south.
round-rock.safety: Round Rock consistently ranks among the safest cities in Texas, with crime rates well below national averages and an active community policing program.

faqs.question: Is Round Rock safe for seniors?
faqs.answer: Round Rock is considered very safe for seniors. The city regularly appears on lists of the safest cities in Texas, with violent and property crime rates significantly below the national average. The Round Rock Police Department maintains active community engagement through neighborhood watch programs and community events. Master-planned neighborhoods with well-lit streets and maintained common areas provide comfortable, secure living environments.

faqs.question: What hospitals are near Round Rock?
faqs.answer: Round Rock is home to two major hospitals: Baylor Scott & White Medical Center - Round Rock, which offers comprehensive services including cardiology, oncology, and orthopedics, and Ascension Seton Williamson, which provides emergency and inpatient care. St. David's Georgetown Hospital is about 15 minutes north, and Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is about 15 minutes west. The Dell Medical School network in Austin is approximately 20 minutes south.

faqs.question: What is there to do for retirees in Round Rock?
faqs.answer: Retirees in Round Rock enjoy a wide range of activities. Old Settlers Park offers 645 acres of trails, fishing, and event space. Dell Diamond hosts Round Rock Express baseball games. Clay Madsen Recreation Center provides pools, fitness classes, and social programs for seniors. The Brushy Creek Trail system is popular for walking and cycling. La Frontera and downtown Round Rock offer dining and shopping, and Austin's cultural attractions are just 20 minutes away.

cedar-park.name: Cedar Park
cedar-park.seoTitle: Retiring to Cedar Park, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
cedar-park.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Cedar Park, TX. Explore Hill Country access, healthcare, trails, and why Cedar Park is a top choice for active retirees in Williamson County.
cedar-park.heroSubtext: Hill Country access, excellent trails, and a growing city with strong healthcare and recreation options.
cedar-park.content:
Cedar Park sits on the western edge of Williamson County where the suburban landscape begins to give way to the rolling hills and live oaks of the Texas Hill Country. With a population of approximately 82,000, Cedar Park offers a well-rounded mix of convenience, natural beauty, and a growing list of amenities that appeal to active retirees.

The city's healthcare needs are served by Cedar Park Regional Medical Center, a full-service hospital with emergency care, surgical services, and outpatient specialties. The hospital has expanded in recent years to meet the demands of the growing population. Additional medical offices, urgent care clinics, and specialist practices are concentrated along the US-183 corridor and near the 1890 Ranch shopping area. Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock and St. David's Georgetown Hospital are each about 15 to 20 minutes away for more specialized care.

Outdoor recreation is where Cedar Park truly shines for retirees. The Brushy Creek Trail system is one of the best paved trail networks in the region, running for miles through green space and connecting neighborhoods, parks, and commercial areas. It is widely used by walkers, joggers, and cyclists of all ages. The Brushy Creek Lake Park provides fishing, picnicking, and a playground area. Cedar Park's western location also provides easy access to Lake Travis for boating and water recreation, and the Hill Country wine trail is a popular day-trip destination.

Shopping and dining have grown substantially in Cedar Park. The 1890 Ranch shopping center anchors the retail landscape with major stores, restaurants, and services. The H-E-B Center at Cedar Park hosts concerts, Texas Stars hockey games, Austin Spurs basketball, and community events throughout the year, providing entertainment options without having to drive into Austin.

Housing in Cedar Park has a median price of approximately $420K, making it the most expensive city in Williamson County. However, the quality of neighborhoods, proximity to Hill Country recreation, and access to healthcare justify the premium for many retirees. There are no dedicated 55+ communities in Cedar Park, but neighborhoods like Ranch at Brushy Creek, Twin Creeks, and Buttercup Creek feature single-story homes and well-maintained settings that attract older adults.

Cedar Park is an ideal choice for retirees who value outdoor recreation, want proximity to both the Hill Country and Austin, and are looking for a city that is growing and investing in its future while still maintaining a manageable, community-oriented feel.
highlights: Hill Country access and scenic beauty
Cedar Park Regional Medical Center
Brushy Creek Trail system
1890 Ranch shopping center
H-E-B Center concerts and events
Proximity to Lake Travis
Brushy Creek Lake Park
Close to Texas wine country
cedar-park.healthcare: Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is the primary hospital, offering emergency care, surgery, and outpatient services. The hospital has expanded recently to meet growing demand. Additional urgent care and specialist offices are located along US-183. Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock and St. David's Georgetown are each 15 to 20 minutes away for more advanced care.
cedar-park.thingsToDo: The Brushy Creek Trail system offers miles of paved paths for walking and cycling. Brushy Creek Lake Park provides fishing and picnicking. The H-E-B Center hosts concerts, hockey, and basketball. 1890 Ranch offers dining and shopping. Lake Travis is a short drive west for boating and recreation. Austin's cultural scene is 20 to 30 minutes south.
cedar-park.safety: Cedar Park is consistently rated as one of the safest cities in Texas, with low crime rates and well-maintained neighborhoods that contribute to a strong sense of community security.

faqs.question: What is there to do for retirees in Cedar Park?
faqs.answer: Cedar Park offers excellent outdoor recreation through the Brushy Creek Trail system, Brushy Creek Lake Park, and easy access to Lake Travis and the Hill Country. The H-E-B Center hosts concerts, hockey, and basketball games. 1890 Ranch provides dining and shopping. Fitness classes and community programs are available through city recreation facilities. Austin's cultural attractions are 20 to 30 minutes away.

faqs.question: What hospitals are near Cedar Park TX?
faqs.answer: Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is the city's primary hospital, offering emergency care, surgical services, and outpatient specialties. Baylor Scott & White Medical Center in Round Rock is about 15 minutes east, and St. David's Georgetown Hospital is approximately 20 minutes north. The Dell Medical School network in Austin is about 25 minutes south.

faqs.question: Is Cedar Park expensive for retirees?
faqs.answer: Cedar Park has the highest median home price in Williamson County at approximately $420K, though homes range from $300K to $600K depending on the neighborhood. While housing costs are higher than cities like Hutto or Taylor, Cedar Park's access to Hill Country recreation, strong healthcare, excellent trails, and proximity to Austin justify the premium for many retirees. The lack of state income tax and senior property tax exemptions help offset the housing costs.

leander.name: Leander
leander.seoTitle: Retiring to Leander, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
leander.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Leander, TX. Explore affordable housing, MetroRail access, golf, and why this fast-growing city is gaining attention from retirees.
leander.heroSubtext: Rapidly growing with affordable homes, MetroRail access, and a Hill Country backdrop.
leander.content:
Leander is one of the fastest-growing cities in Texas, and its combination of relatively affordable housing, growing amenities, and Hill Country setting is beginning to attract retirees alongside the young families that have fueled its growth. With a population of approximately 75,000, Leander sits just west and north of Cedar Park and offers many of the same geographic advantages at a lower price point.

Housing is one of Leander's biggest draws for retirees. The median home price is approximately $370K, which is noticeably lower than neighboring Cedar Park. The Crystal Falls area in western Leander is particularly popular with older adults, offering newer homes with Hill Country views, the Crystal Falls Golf Club, and a quieter, more scenic setting than the eastern side of the city. Other neighborhoods like Bryson and Mason Hills provide single-story options with modern finishes and community amenities.

Leander does not have its own hospital, but Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is just minutes to the south, and St. David's Georgetown Hospital is approximately 20 minutes to the northeast. Urgent care clinics and medical offices have expanded rapidly along US-183 and Ronald Reagan Boulevard as the population has grown. Most healthcare needs can be met locally, with more specialized care available in Round Rock or Austin.

One of Leander's unique advantages is the Capital MetroRail Red Line station. The MetroRail runs from Leander to downtown Austin, providing a car-free option for day trips into the city. While the service is not frequent enough for daily commuting by most standards, it is a convenient option for retirees who want to attend events, visit museums, or enjoy Austin's restaurant and music scene without driving.

Recreation in Leander includes the Crystal Falls Golf Club, several community parks, and growing trail connectivity. The city's western location provides easy access to Hill Country drives, wineries, and Lake Travis. Leander's restaurant and retail scene is growing rapidly, with new developments along US-183 and Ronald Reagan Boulevard adding dining and shopping options regularly.

Leander is a strong choice for retirees who want newer, more affordable housing than Cedar Park, do not need a dedicated 55+ community, and appreciate the combination of Hill Country scenery and access to Austin via MetroRail. The city is still very much in its growth phase, which means some areas are still developing, but that also means new amenities and services continue to arrive.
highlights: More affordable than Cedar Park with similar Hill Country access
Crystal Falls Golf Club and neighborhood
Capital MetroRail station with service to Austin
Near Cedar Park Regional Medical Center
Hill Country views and scenic surroundings
Rapidly growing restaurant and retail scene
Access to Lake Travis and wineries
leander.healthcare: Leander does not have its own hospital, but Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is just minutes south. St. David's Georgetown Hospital is about 20 minutes northeast. Urgent care clinics and medical offices along US-183 and Ronald Reagan Boulevard have expanded rapidly in recent years. More specialized care is available in Round Rock or Austin, both within 25 to 35 minutes.
leander.thingsToDo: Crystal Falls Golf Club is a highlight for golfers. Community parks and expanding trails provide outdoor recreation. The MetroRail station offers car-free day trips to Austin for dining, museums, and entertainment. Lake Travis and Hill Country wineries are a short drive west. The local restaurant and shopping scene is growing steadily.
leander.safety: Leander maintains low crime rates and benefits from a growing police department that has kept pace with the city's rapid population growth.

faqs.question: Is Leander TX a good place to retire?
faqs.answer: Leander is increasingly attractive for retirees looking for affordable housing with Hill Country access. The median home price of $370K is lower than Cedar Park and Georgetown. The MetroRail station provides a car-free connection to Austin. Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is minutes away. The Crystal Falls area offers golf, scenic views, and newer single-story homes. The main consideration is that Leander is still growing rapidly, so some areas are still developing amenities.

faqs.question: Does Leander have a hospital?
faqs.answer: Leander does not have its own hospital, but Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is just a few minutes south of the city. St. David's Georgetown Hospital is approximately 20 minutes northeast. Urgent care clinics and medical offices along US-183 and Ronald Reagan Boulevard serve most routine healthcare needs. For specialized care, Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock is about 25 minutes east.

faqs.question: What neighborhoods in Leander are good for retirees?
faqs.answer: Crystal Falls in western Leander is the most popular area for retirees, offering Hill Country views, a golf club, and newer single-story homes. Bryson and Mason Hills also provide modern homes with community amenities. Travisso is a master-planned community with trails and a resort-style pool. Block House Creek is an established neighborhood closer to Cedar Park with more affordable options.

pflugerville.name: Pflugerville
pflugerville.seoTitle: Retiring to Pflugerville, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
pflugerville.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Pflugerville, TX. Explore affordable housing, diverse community, Lake Pflugerville, and convenient access to Round Rock and Austin.
pflugerville.heroSubtext: Diverse, affordable, and conveniently located between Round Rock and Austin.
pflugerville.content:
Pflugerville offers retirees a welcoming, diverse community with affordable housing and a convenient location between Round Rock and Austin. With a population of approximately 72,000, Pflugerville has grown from a small farming town into a thriving suburb while retaining a strong sense of community identity rooted in its German-Texas heritage.

Housing affordability is one of Pflugerville's biggest advantages. The median home price is approximately $350K, making it one of the more budget-friendly options in the western half of Williamson County. Neighborhoods throughout the city offer single-story homes in well-maintained subdivisions, and the lower price point means retirees can often find more house for their money compared to Cedar Park or Round Rock. Falcon Pointe, Blackhawk, and Avalon are among the neighborhoods that attract older adults.

Pflugerville does not have its own hospital, but its location provides excellent access to the major hospitals in Round Rock. Baylor Scott & White Medical Center and Ascension Seton Williamson are both within a 10- to 15-minute drive. Urgent care clinics and medical offices are located throughout the city, particularly along Pecan Street and the FM 685 corridor. The proximity to Round Rock's healthcare infrastructure is a significant practical advantage.

Lake Pflugerville is the centerpiece of the city's outdoor recreation. The 180-acre lake features a 3-mile paved trail around its perimeter that is popular with walkers, joggers, and cyclists. Fishing and kayaking are available on the lake. The Pflugerville Recreation Center offers fitness equipment, group exercise classes, a gymnasium, and community programming, including activities tailored for seniors. Heritage Park and Pfluger Park provide additional green space, playgrounds, and picnic areas.

Pflugerville's cultural diversity is reflected in its dining scene, which features a wide range of cuisines from Tex-Mex and barbecue to Vietnamese, Indian, and Korean restaurants. The city hosts community events throughout the year, including Pflugerville Pfall Pfest and Deutschen Pfest, which celebrate the city's German-Texas roots.

For retirees who value affordability, diversity, and convenient access to healthcare and urban amenities without paying premium prices, Pflugerville is a practical and welcoming choice. The city's proximity to both Round Rock and Austin means that most services, entertainment, and medical care are within a short drive.
highlights: Affordable housing with median price around $350K
Lake Pflugerville with 3-mile walking trail
Pflugerville Recreation Center with senior programs
Diverse dining scene reflecting multicultural community
Close to Baylor Scott & White and Ascension Seton hospitals in Round Rock
German-Texas heritage and community festivals
Convenient location between Round Rock and Austin
pflugerville.healthcare: Pflugerville does not have its own hospital, but Baylor Scott & White Medical Center and Ascension Seton Williamson in Round Rock are both within 10 to 15 minutes. Urgent care clinics and medical offices are located along Pecan Street and FM 685. The proximity to Round Rock's comprehensive healthcare infrastructure provides excellent access to both routine and specialized care.
pflugerville.thingsToDo: Lake Pflugerville offers a 3-mile paved walking trail, fishing, and kayaking. The Pflugerville Recreation Center provides fitness classes and senior programming. The city's diverse restaurant scene spans multiple cuisines. Community festivals including Deutschen Pfest and Pfall Pfest celebrate local heritage. Austin and Round Rock attractions are minutes away.
pflugerville.safety: Pflugerville maintains crime rates below the national average and benefits from a responsive police department and active community engagement in neighborhood safety.

faqs.question: Is Pflugerville affordable for retirees?
faqs.answer: Pflugerville is one of the more affordable cities in the western part of Williamson County, with a median home price of approximately $350K. Homes range from $250K to $480K, providing options for various budgets. The city offers good value compared to Cedar Park and Round Rock while maintaining convenient access to the same hospitals, shopping, and amenities. Property tax rates are around 2.3%, but senior homestead exemptions help reduce the burden.

faqs.question: What is Lake Pflugerville?
faqs.answer: Lake Pflugerville is a 180-acre recreational lake with a 3-mile paved trail around its perimeter. The trail is popular with walkers, joggers, and cyclists and provides a scenic, flat route ideal for older adults. The lake allows fishing and kayaking. Adjacent park areas include picnic pavilions and green space. It is one of the most used outdoor amenities in the city.

faqs.question: What hospitals are near Pflugerville TX?
faqs.answer: Pflugerville does not have its own hospital, but two major facilities in Round Rock are within 10 to 15 minutes: Baylor Scott & White Medical Center, which offers comprehensive services including cardiology and oncology, and Ascension Seton Williamson, which provides emergency and inpatient care. Urgent care clinics throughout Pflugerville handle routine medical needs. Austin's hospital network is about 20 minutes south.

hutto.name: Hutto
hutto.seoTitle: Retiring to Hutto, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
hutto.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Hutto, TX. Explore affordable housing, small-town atmosphere, and community-oriented living in one of Williamson County's most welcoming cities.
hutto.heroSubtext: Small-town charm and affordable homes in a welcoming, fast-growing community.
hutto.content:
Hutto is a small but rapidly growing city in eastern Williamson County that offers retirees something increasingly hard to find in the Austin metro: genuine small-town atmosphere at a truly affordable price point. With a population of approximately 45,000, Hutto has grown significantly in recent years but retains a close-knit community feel that larger cities in the county have outgrown.

Affordability is Hutto's calling card. The median home price is approximately $320K, making it one of the most budget-friendly cities in Williamson County. For retirees on fixed incomes or those looking to downsize and preserve savings, Hutto provides modern, well-built homes in master-planned communities at prices that are $50K to $100K less than comparable homes in Round Rock or Cedar Park. Neighborhoods like Star Ranch, Hutto Parke, and Riverwalk feature single-story homes with community amenities including pools, parks, and walking paths.

Hutto does not have its own hospital, but the major hospitals in Round Rock, specifically Baylor Scott & White Medical Center and Ascension Seton Williamson, are approximately 15 to 20 minutes west via US-79 and the 130 Toll Road. Urgent care clinics and primary care offices have expanded in Hutto as the population has grown, and most routine healthcare needs can be met within the city.

Recreation in Hutto centers around its parks and community events. Hutto Lake Park is a popular spot for fishing, walking, and picnicking. Fritz Park hosts community gatherings and youth sports. The Hutto Public Library and community center offer programming for adults including book clubs, fitness activities, and social events. The city's calendar includes events like Old Tyme Days and holiday celebrations that bring the community together.

Hutto is known for its hippo mascot, a quirky local tradition that stems from a legend about a hippo that escaped from a circus train in the early 1900s. Concrete hippo statues are scattered throughout the city, and the mascot has become a beloved symbol of Hutto's character and sense of humor.

For retirees who are comfortable with a quieter, smaller-town lifestyle and prioritize affordability, Hutto is an excellent option. The trade-off is fewer local dining and shopping options compared to Round Rock or Cedar Park, and lower walkability. However, the strong community bonds, affordable housing, and reasonable access to Round Rock's amenities make Hutto a practical and comfortable place to retire.
highlights: Very affordable housing with median around $320K
Genuine small-town community atmosphere
Hutto Lake Park for fishing and walking
Fritz Park and community events
15-20 minutes from Round Rock hospitals
Rapidly growing with new amenities
Famous hippo mascot and community spirit
hutto.healthcare: Hutto does not have its own hospital. Baylor Scott & White Medical Center and Ascension Seton Williamson in Round Rock are 15 to 20 minutes west. Urgent care clinics and primary care offices within Hutto have expanded with the city's growth. Taylor Regional Hospital is about 15 minutes east for basic emergency care.
hutto.thingsToDo: Hutto Lake Park offers fishing, walking, and picnicking. Fritz Park hosts community events and recreation. The Hutto Public Library provides adult programming including book clubs and social events. Community celebrations like Old Tyme Days bring residents together. Round Rock's dining, shopping, and entertainment are a short drive west.
hutto.safety: Hutto maintains a small-town safety profile with low crime rates and a community-oriented police department that benefits from the city's close-knit atmosphere.

faqs.question: Is Hutto TX affordable for retirees?
faqs.answer: Hutto is one of the most affordable cities in Williamson County, with a median home price of approximately $320K and homes available starting in the low $230Ks. Property tax rates are around 2.25%, and senior homestead exemptions help reduce the burden. For retirees looking to stretch their budget, Hutto offers modern homes in master-planned communities at significantly lower prices than Round Rock, Cedar Park, or Georgetown.

faqs.question: What is there to do in Hutto TX?
faqs.answer: Hutto offers Hutto Lake Park for fishing and walking, Fritz Park for community gatherings, and a library with adult programming. The city hosts events like Old Tyme Days and holiday celebrations. While Hutto's entertainment options are smaller than larger cities, Round Rock's extensive dining, shopping, and recreation are about 15 minutes west. The city's community spirit and small-town events create a social atmosphere that many retirees enjoy.

faqs.question: How far is Hutto from hospitals?
faqs.answer: Baylor Scott & White Medical Center and Ascension Seton Williamson in Round Rock are approximately 15 to 20 minutes west of Hutto via US-79 or the 130 Toll Road. Taylor Regional Hospital is about 15 minutes east. Urgent care clinics within Hutto handle routine medical needs. For specialized care, the Austin medical network is approximately 30 to 40 minutes south.

taylor.name: Taylor
taylor.seoTitle: Retiring to Taylor, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
taylor.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Taylor, TX. Explore the most affordable housing in Williamson County, historic downtown charm, and new energy from the Samsung campus.
taylor.heroSubtext: Historic small-town charm, the most affordable homes in the county, and a community on the rise.
taylor.content:
Taylor is a historic small town in eastern Williamson County that offers retirees the most affordable housing in the area, a genuine downtown square with character, and a community that is experiencing new energy and investment. With a population of approximately 18,000, Taylor has deep agricultural roots and a slower pace of life that many retirees find appealing after years in larger cities.

Affordability is Taylor's defining advantage. The median home price is approximately $280K, the lowest in Williamson County. For retirees on fixed incomes, this means the possibility of purchasing a home outright or having a very manageable mortgage payment. Homes range from charming older bungalows near downtown to newer construction in growing subdivisions on the edges of town. Property tax rates are around 2.1%, and senior homestead exemptions provide additional relief.

Taylor Regional Hospital serves the city with emergency care, inpatient services, and basic outpatient specialties. While it is a smaller facility than the major hospitals in Round Rock or Georgetown, it provides essential services and a local option for routine and urgent care. For more specialized treatment, Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock is approximately 20 to 25 minutes west. The growth of medical offices and clinics in Taylor has been modest compared to the western part of the county, so retirees with complex medical needs should factor in the drive to Round Rock or Austin.

Taylor's historic downtown square is a point of pride. The square features local restaurants, shops, a restored movie theater, and murals that celebrate the city's heritage. The International Barbecue Championship, held annually, draws visitors from across the state. Louie Mueller Barbecue, located on Taylor's main street, is one of the most acclaimed barbecue restaurants in Texas.

The Samsung semiconductor campus currently under construction just southeast of Taylor is bringing significant investment and attention to the area. While the campus itself is industrial, the surrounding economic activity is expected to bring new restaurants, retail, and services to Taylor in the coming years, gradually expanding the amenities available to residents.

Recreation in Taylor includes Murphy Park, Bull Branch Park, and the Taylor Regional Park and Sports Complex. The city's Heritage Square and public library host community events and programming. For retirees who enjoy a small-town lifestyle with a strong sense of community history, Taylor offers an authentic experience at a price point that is increasingly rare in the Austin metro area.
highlights: Most affordable housing in Williamson County (median $280K)
Historic downtown square with shops and restaurants
Louie Mueller Barbecue - Texas landmark
Taylor Regional Hospital
Samsung semiconductor campus bringing new investment
International Barbecue Championship
Murphy Park and community recreation
Strong agricultural heritage and community identity
taylor.healthcare: Taylor Regional Hospital provides emergency care, inpatient services, and basic outpatient specialties. For more comprehensive care, Baylor Scott & White Medical Center in Round Rock is 20 to 25 minutes west. Medical offices and clinics in Taylor are growing but are less extensive than in the western part of the county. Retirees with complex medical needs should plan for occasional trips to Round Rock or Austin.
taylor.thingsToDo: Taylor's historic downtown square offers local dining, shopping, and community events. Louie Mueller Barbecue is a must-visit Texas institution. Murphy Park and Bull Branch Park provide outdoor recreation. The public library and Heritage Square host community programming. The annual International Barbecue Championship draws visitors statewide. Samsung's nearby campus is expected to bring new restaurants and retail.
taylor.safety: Taylor maintains a small-town safety profile with low crime rates and a police department that is closely connected to the community it serves.

faqs.question: Is Taylor TX the most affordable city in Williamson County?
faqs.answer: Yes, Taylor has the lowest median home price in Williamson County at approximately $280K, with homes available starting in the low $190Ks. For retirees on fixed incomes, Taylor offers the opportunity to own a home outright or keep housing costs very low. Property tax rates of around 2.1% are among the lowest in the county. The trade-off is fewer local amenities and a longer drive to major hospitals and shopping compared to cities like Round Rock or Cedar Park.

faqs.question: Does Taylor TX have a hospital?
faqs.answer: Taylor Regional Hospital provides emergency care, inpatient services, and basic outpatient specialties. It is a smaller facility than the major hospitals in Round Rock but serves essential local healthcare needs. For specialized care, Baylor Scott & White Medical Center in Round Rock is approximately 20 to 25 minutes west, and the Austin medical network is about 35 minutes south.

faqs.question: What is the Samsung campus doing for Taylor TX?
faqs.answer: Samsung is building a major semiconductor manufacturing campus just southeast of Taylor, bringing billions of dollars in investment to the area. While the campus is industrial and will not directly serve retirees, the economic activity is expected to bring new restaurants, retail, services, and infrastructure improvements to Taylor over the coming years. This investment is gradually transforming Taylor from a quiet agricultural town into a community with growing amenities and opportunities.

liberty-hill.name: Liberty Hill
liberty-hill.seoTitle: Retiring to Liberty Hill, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
liberty-hill.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Liberty Hill, TX. Explore Hill Country scenery, spacious homesites, and a growing community with a rural, scenic atmosphere.
liberty-hill.heroSubtext: Hill Country living with scenic beauty, spacious properties, and a growing community spirit.
liberty-hill.content:
Liberty Hill is a small, rapidly growing community in the northwestern corner of Williamson County that offers retirees something unique in the area: genuine Hill Country living with rolling terrain, live oak trees, and spacious homesites, all while remaining within reasonable reach of Georgetown, Cedar Park, and Austin. With a population of approximately 8,000, Liberty Hill is still small enough to feel rural and peaceful, but growth is bringing new homes, businesses, and amenities at a steady pace.

The landscape is Liberty Hill's greatest asset. Unlike the flatter terrain of Round Rock, Pflugerville, or Hutto, Liberty Hill sits in the transitional zone where the Blackland Prairie meets the Edwards Plateau. The result is rolling hills, dramatic sunsets, native wildflowers in spring, and a sense of open space that is increasingly rare this close to a major metro area. Many homes sit on larger lots, often an acre or more, which appeals to retirees who want room to breathe, garden, or simply enjoy a view.

Housing in Liberty Hill has a median price of approximately $380K, which reflects the larger lot sizes and scenic settings rather than urban density. Options range from newer homes in master-planned communities to custom-built properties on acreage. The Liberty Hill area has seen significant new construction, with neighborhoods offering modern floor plans and community amenities.

Liberty Hill does not have its own hospital. Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is approximately 20 minutes south, and St. David's Georgetown Hospital is about 20 to 25 minutes east. Urgent care and primary care options within Liberty Hill are limited but growing. Retirees who choose Liberty Hill should be comfortable with a short drive for healthcare needs.

Recreation in Liberty Hill leans toward the outdoor and rural. Hiking, horseback riding, bird watching, and enjoying the natural landscape are primary activities. The area is close to the Highland Lakes chain, and day trips to Inks Lake, Buchanan Dam, and the Balcones Canyonlands National Wildlife Refuge are easy to make. Local dining options are growing, and Georgetown's downtown square is a reasonable drive for shopping and entertainment.

Liberty Hill is the right choice for retirees who prioritize space, scenery, and quiet over walkability and urban convenience. It offers a lifestyle that is more rural than suburban, with the understanding that most errands and medical appointments will require a drive to a neighboring city.
highlights: Hill Country scenery with rolling terrain and live oaks
Larger homesites, often an acre or more
Peaceful, rural atmosphere with growing amenities
Close to Highland Lakes for recreation
20 minutes from Cedar Park and Georgetown hospitals
Wildflowers and dramatic sunsets
Growing restaurant and retail options
liberty-hill.healthcare: Liberty Hill does not have its own hospital. Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is approximately 20 minutes south, and St. David's Georgetown Hospital is 20 to 25 minutes east. Local urgent care and primary care options are limited but growing. Retirees should plan for a short drive to Cedar Park or Georgetown for most medical needs.
liberty-hill.thingsToDo: Liberty Hill's recreation centers on outdoor activities including hiking, horseback riding, and enjoying the Hill Country landscape. The Highland Lakes chain is nearby for boating and fishing. Georgetown's historic downtown square is a reasonable drive for dining and shopping. Local dining options are expanding as the community grows.
liberty-hill.safety: Liberty Hill benefits from a low crime rate characteristic of small, rural communities, with an active Williamson County Sheriff's presence and engaged residents who look out for their neighbors.

faqs.question: What is Liberty Hill TX like for retirees?
faqs.answer: Liberty Hill offers a Hill Country lifestyle with rolling terrain, spacious homesites, and a rural atmosphere. It appeals to retirees who want scenic beauty, space, and quiet rather than urban convenience. Homes often sit on larger lots with views. The community is growing with new restaurants and shops. The trade-off is limited local healthcare and lower walkability, with most errands requiring a drive to Cedar Park or Georgetown.

faqs.question: How far is Liberty Hill from hospitals?
faqs.answer: Cedar Park Regional Medical Center is approximately 20 minutes south of Liberty Hill, and St. David's Georgetown Hospital is about 20 to 25 minutes east. Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock is approximately 30 minutes away. Local urgent care options within Liberty Hill are limited but expanding. Retirees should be comfortable with a short drive for healthcare appointments.

faqs.question: Is Liberty Hill TX growing?
faqs.answer: Liberty Hill is one of the fastest-growing communities in Williamson County. New neighborhoods, restaurants, and retail options are being added regularly. The community has attracted significant residential development due to its Hill Country setting and relative proximity to Austin and Georgetown. While growth is changing the area, the larger lot sizes and rolling terrain help maintain the rural, scenic character that draws people to Liberty Hill.

jarrell.name: Jarrell
jarrell.seoTitle: Retiring to Jarrell, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
jarrell.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Jarrell, TX. Explore affordable housing, small-town living, and future growth potential in this quiet northern Williamson County community.
jarrell.heroSubtext: Affordable, quiet, and positioned for growth at the northern edge of Williamson County.
jarrell.content:
Jarrell is a small community at the northern edge of Williamson County, positioned along I-35 between Georgetown and the Bell County line. With a population of approximately 5,000, Jarrell is one of the smallest incorporated cities in the county, but it has begun to attract new development and residents drawn by its affordable housing and small-town atmosphere.

Affordability is Jarrell's primary draw. The median home price is approximately $300K, which is significantly below Georgetown, Round Rock, or Cedar Park. New home construction in recent years has added modern subdivisions with single-story options, community amenities, and contemporary floor plans at prices that are hard to find closer to Austin. For retirees who want a newer home without stretching their budget, Jarrell delivers real value.

Jarrell does not have its own hospital or significant medical infrastructure. St. David's Georgetown Hospital is approximately 15 minutes south on I-35, which is the closest full-service facility. Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock is about 25 minutes south. Local medical offices and urgent care are very limited, so retirees in Jarrell should plan to drive to Georgetown for most healthcare needs. This is the most significant trade-off of living in Jarrell.

The community is tight-knit and friendly. Jarrell has a small commercial area along I-35 with basic services, and a growing number of restaurants and shops. The Jarrell Community Center hosts events and provides a gathering space for residents. Parks within the newer subdivisions provide walking paths, playgrounds, and picnic areas. For more extensive recreation, Georgetown's parks, trails, and downtown square are a short drive south.

Jarrell's position along I-35 provides straightforward highway access to Georgetown, Round Rock, and Austin, though it adds distance to most destinations compared to living further south. The city is considered a future growth area, with new residential and commercial development gradually expanding the amenities and services available to residents.

Jarrell is best suited for retirees who prioritize affordability above all else, are comfortable with a very small-town setting, and do not mind driving to Georgetown for healthcare, dining, and most services. The community is welcoming, the homes are new and well-priced, and the quiet lifestyle appeals to those who want to slow down in a meaningful way.
highlights: Affordable housing with median around $300K
New construction with modern floor plans
15 minutes from St. David's Georgetown Hospital
Tight-knit, small-town community
I-35 access for easy travel south
Future growth area with expanding amenities
Quiet, peaceful lifestyle
jarrell.healthcare: Jarrell does not have its own hospital or significant medical facilities. St. David's Georgetown Hospital is approximately 15 minutes south on I-35. Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock is about 25 minutes south. Local medical offices are very limited. Retirees in Jarrell should plan to drive to Georgetown for most healthcare needs.
jarrell.thingsToDo: Jarrell offers a quiet, small-town lifestyle with community events at the Jarrell Community Center, walking paths in newer subdivisions, and basic local dining. Georgetown's parks, trails, historic downtown, and recreation facilities are a 15-minute drive south. Lake Georgetown and Garey Park are easy day-trip destinations.
jarrell.safety: Jarrell benefits from the low crime rates typical of small, rural communities in northern Williamson County, with coverage from the Williamson County Sheriff's Office.

faqs.question: Is Jarrell TX affordable for retirees?
faqs.answer: Jarrell is one of the most affordable cities in Williamson County, with a median home price of approximately $300K and new construction starting in the low $220Ks. Property tax rates are around 2.15%. For retirees on fixed incomes, Jarrell offers the possibility of purchasing a newer home at a significantly lower price than Georgetown, Round Rock, or Cedar Park. The trade-off is limited local amenities and a 15-minute drive to Georgetown for healthcare and most services.

faqs.question: How far is Jarrell from Georgetown?
faqs.answer: Jarrell is approximately 15 minutes north of Georgetown via I-35. This puts residents within easy reach of St. David's Georgetown Hospital, Georgetown's historic downtown square, Garey Park, Lake Georgetown, and the full range of shopping and dining options in Georgetown. The drive is straightforward along I-35 with no significant traffic in most conditions.

faqs.question: Is Jarrell TX growing?
faqs.answer: Jarrell is experiencing steady growth with new residential subdivisions and gradual commercial development along I-35. The city is positioned as a future growth area as the Austin metro expands northward. New homes, restaurants, and basic services are being added, though the pace is slower than larger cities in the county. Retirees who buy in Jarrell now may benefit from increasing amenities and property value appreciation over time.

florence.name: Florence
florence.seoTitle: Retiring to Florence, TX | Senior Relocation Guide
florence.metaDescription: Complete guide to retiring in Florence, TX. Explore the most affordable and rural option in Williamson County with peaceful countryside living and Hill Country lake access.
florence.heroSubtext: Peaceful countryside living at the lowest cost in the county, with Hill Country lakes nearby.
florence.content:
Florence is the most rural community in Williamson County and offers retirees something that is becoming exceedingly rare in the Austin metro region: genuine country living at a very affordable price. With a population of approximately 1,200, Florence is a small, quiet town in the northwestern part of the county where the landscape opens up into ranch land, live oak groves, and rolling Hill Country terrain.

Affordability is Florence's strongest advantage. The median home price is approximately $270K, the lowest in Williamson County. Properties often include larger lots or acreage, and the lower cost of entry means retirees can purchase a home outright or maintain very low housing costs. For those relocating from expensive metros, Florence's pricing is particularly striking. Property tax rates are around 2.0%, among the lowest in the county, and senior homestead exemptions provide additional relief.

Florence does not have its own hospital, medical clinics, or significant commercial infrastructure. St. David's Georgetown Hospital is approximately 25 to 30 minutes south, and that is the primary healthcare option for Florence residents. Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock is roughly 40 minutes away. This is the most important consideration for retirees evaluating Florence. Living here requires comfort with driving for virtually all medical care, grocery shopping, and services. The nearest H-E-B grocery store is in Georgetown.

What Florence offers in return is peace, space, and natural beauty. The town sits near the northern reaches of Williamson County, where the land transitions into the Hill Country lake region. Stillhouse Hollow Lake and Belton Lake in neighboring Bell County are within a reasonable drive, offering boating, fishing, and lakeside recreation. The countryside around Florence is popular with birdwatchers, horseback riders, and anyone who simply wants to sit on a porch and watch the sunset over open land.

Florence has a small downtown area with a few local businesses, a post office, and a community center. The Florence Volunteer Fire Department and local civic organizations form the backbone of community life. Neighbors know each other, and there is a genuine sense of mutual support that comes with small-town living.

Florence is not for everyone. It requires independence, comfort with driving, and a willingness to live without nearby urban conveniences. But for retirees who dream of a quiet, rural lifestyle, want to keep costs as low as possible, and find joy in open space and natural surroundings, Florence offers an honest, unpretentious version of the Hill Country retirement that many people romanticize but few places can actually deliver at this price point.
highlights: Most affordable housing in Williamson County (median $270K)
Genuine rural, countryside atmosphere
Larger lots and acreage available
Proximity to Stillhouse Hollow Lake and Belton Lake
Lowest property tax rates in the county (around 2.0%)
Peaceful, tight-knit community
Hill Country landscape and wildlife

popularNeighborhoods: Rural acreage properties along FM 487 and FM 970

florence.healthcare: Florence does not have its own hospital or medical clinics. St. David's Georgetown Hospital is approximately 25 to 30 minutes south, serving as the primary healthcare option. Baylor Scott & White in Round Rock is roughly 40 minutes away. Retirees in Florence should be comfortable driving to Georgetown for all medical appointments, prescriptions, and urgent care needs.
florence.thingsToDo: Florence's recreation centers on outdoor and rural activities: enjoying the countryside, birdwatching, horseback riding, and gardening. Stillhouse Hollow Lake and Belton Lake are within driving distance for boating and fishing. Georgetown's downtown, parks, and community events are 25 to 30 minutes south. The community center hosts local gatherings and events.
florence.safety: Florence is a very safe, small community where residents know each other and look out for one another. The Williamson County Sheriff's Office provides law enforcement coverage.

faqs.question: Is Florence TX a good place to retire?
faqs.answer: Florence is an excellent choice for retirees who prioritize affordability, peace, and rural living above all else. With the lowest median home price in Williamson County at $270K and property tax rates around 2.0%, it is the most budget-friendly option in the area. The trade-offs are significant: no local hospital, very limited commercial services, and a 25- to 30-minute drive to Georgetown for groceries, healthcare, and most errands. Retirees who are comfortable with this lifestyle will find a genuinely peaceful, tight-knit community.

faqs.question: How far is Florence TX from hospitals?
faqs.answer: Florence is approximately 25 to 30 minutes from St. David's Georgetown Hospital, which is the nearest full-service medical facility. Baylor Scott & White Medical Center in Round Rock is about 40 minutes away. There are no hospitals, urgent care clinics, or significant medical offices in Florence itself. Retirees with ongoing medical needs should carefully consider this distance when evaluating Florence as a retirement location.

faqs.question: What is Florence TX like?
faqs.answer: Florence is a very small, rural town with approximately 1,200 residents in the northwestern part of Williamson County. It features open ranch land, Hill Country scenery, and a tight-knit community where neighbors know each other. There is a small downtown with a few local businesses and a community center. The pace of life is slow and quiet. It is the most rural option in the county, appealing to retirees who want country living near the Hill Country lakes at a very affordable price.
